> 
> So it comes down to whether you mean fixed physical topology or 
> fixed logical topology.
> 

Or both.  I would imagine you can fix both and still create a learning
machine.  But I think Colin summed it up nicely.  I think you're sort of stuck
on the input->output training scenario.  I doubt this is the real mechanism
behind learning in biological systems.  I agree the topology changes in human
brains but would be willing to bet that's a different-level mechanism that
sort of goes beyond the basics.  When you look at a picture of a horse and are
told "horse", I don't believe you just grew neurons or even "adjusted weights"
(or whatever the biological analog is).  However, what I know of neuroscience
can be summed up on a nice index card; I'm just guessing.  Regardless, I think
we should all be careful about throwing around the concept of "learning" so
broadly.

- jeff
